literature_search.ai_response:
To locate recent, relevant papers I will search the literature database for keywords focused on \synaptic plasticity\ in the \hippocampus\ and return the top recent results for review. The next step is a targeted literature search limited to recent years to surface high-quality articles and reviews.## Plan
I searched recent neuroscience literature for papers that specifically address synaptic plasticity and hippocampal function, then selected the most relevant recent articles (high‑impact journals and direct relevance). Below are the top results with key metadata and links; tell me which you want the full text of and I can attempt to retrieve the full paper for deeper review.

---

## Recent papers on synaptic plasticity in the hippocampus

### 1) **Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus**  
- **Authors:** Sachin P. Vaidya, Guanchun Li, Raymond A. Chitwood, Yiding Li … **Jeffrey C. Magee**  
- **Journal:** *Nature Neuroscience*  
- **Published:** 04 June 2025  
- **Summary:** Longitudinal tracking of CA1 place cells across 7 days shows progressive stabilization of place fields linked to behavioral-timescale synaptic plasticity (BTSP); proposes a cascade-type state model for increasing neuron-specific plasticity and memory stability.  
- **Link:** [Formation of an expanding memory representation in the hippocampus](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-025-01986-3)  
- ![Figure preview — Formation of an expanding memory representation](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-025-01986-3/MediaObjects/41593_2025_1986_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Why it’s relevant:** Directly ties hippocampal place-field emergence/stability to synaptic plasticity mechanisms on behaviorally relevant timescales.

---

### 2) **Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons**  
- **Authors:** Kevin C. Gonzalez, Adrian Negrean, Zhenrui Liao, Satoshi Terada, Guofeng Zhang, Sungmoo Lee, Katalin Ócsai, Balázs J. Rózsa, Michael Z. Lin, Franck Polleux … **Attila Losonczy**  
- **Journal:** *Nature*  
- **Published:** 18 December 2024 (article metadata shows 2025 volume)  
- **Summary:** Uses an all‑optical approach to monitor spatiotemporal tuning and synaptic activity in hippocampal CA1 neurons in behaving animals, linking synaptic plasticity to the emergence of place‑field feature selectivity.  
- **Link:** [Synaptic basis of feature selectivity in hippocampal neurons](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-08325-9?error=cookies_not_supported&code=99fed048-9696-4c0c-81ab-d1c517d6a190)  
- ![Figure preview — Synaptic basis of feature selectivity](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-024-08325-9/MediaObjects/41586_2024_8325_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Why it’s relevant:** Offers direct, single‑neuron synaptic-level evidence of how plasticity contributes to hippocampal coding during behavior.

---

### 3) **Distinct neuronal populations in the human brain combine content and context**  
- **Authors:** Marcel Bausch, Johannes Niediek, Thomas P. Reber, Sina Mackay, Jan Boström, Christian E. Elger … Florian Mormann  
- **Journal:** *Nature*  
- **Published:** 07 January 2026  
- **Summary:** Single‑neuron recordings from neurosurgical patients show separable stimulus-modulated and context‑modulated neurons across medial temporal structures, including the hippocampus; relevant for understanding how neuronal populations combine item and context — implications for plasticity-based encoding.  
- **Link:** [Distinct neuronal populations in the human brain combine content and context](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-025-09910-2)  
- ![Figure preview — Distinct neuronal populations](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41586-025-09910-2/MediaObjects/41586_2025_9910_Fig1_HTML.png)  
- **Why it’s relevant:** While not exclusively a plasticity mechanisms paper, it links hippocampal single‑neuron coding and population structure to memory representations that likely depend on synaptic plasticity.

---

## Options / Next steps
- If you want the full text of any of these papers, I can attempt to retrieve the complete article(s) (if publicly available) and extract sections you care about (methods, figures, results). Let me know which paper(s) to fetch.

software_docs_entitysdk.user: How to list all cell morphologies in Python using the entitysdk?
software_docs_entitysdk.expected_output:
## Overview

Below are examples showing how to retrieve (list) all CellMorphology entities using the Open Brain Platform Python SDK (entitysdk). I include:

- A minimal example that fetches a limited set (safe default).
- A full \u201cget all\u201d pattern that pages through results until all items are retrieved.
- Notes about pagination and total_items (required by EntityCore rules).

All examples assume you have an authenticated `client` instance from the entitysdk (see your project/docs for authentication). Replace any placeholder values (API keys, endpoints) per your environment.

---

## 1) Minimal / quick preview (limit results)

This fetches a limited number of morphologies (e.g., 10) \u2014 useful for quick checks.

```python
# Example: quick fetch (limit 10)
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

# instantiate client (fill in auth details per your setup)
client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")  # adapt to your auth method

# search for CellMorphology with a limit (safe preview)
morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology, limit=10).all()

print(f\Retrieved {len(morphs)} morphologies (preview)\")
for m in morphs:
    print(m.id, m.name)
```

---

## 2) Recommended: Retrieve ALL morphologies with pagination (robust)

The EntityCore \u201cGET ALL\u201d may paginate. This pattern requests pages until all items are retrieved. It also prints the reported total_items so you can decide whether to continue if needed.

```python
from entitysdk import Client
from entitysdk.entities import CellMorphology

client = Client(api_key=\YOUR_API_KEY\")

# page_size should be <= service max (commonly 10); adapt if docs show different max
page_size = 10
page = 1
all_morphs = []

while True:
    result = client.search_entity(
        entity_type=CellMorphology,
        limit=page_size,
        offset=(page - 1) * page_size  # note: some clients use page/offset; adjust if client API differs
    ).page(page)  # if client provides a page method; otherwise use offset/limit pattern

    # If your client returns a wrapper with items and total_items:
    items = result.items if hasattr(result, \items\") else result  # adapt to the client response structure
    total_items = getattr(result,       otal_items\", None)

    # Collect items
    all_morphs.extend(items)

    # Display progress
    if total_items is not None:
        print(f\Fetched page {page}. collected {len(all_morphs)} of {total_items}\")

    # Stop when fewer items returned than page_size OR we've reached total_items
    if len(items) < page_size:
        break
    if total_items is not None and len(all_morphs) >= total_items:
        break

    page += 1

print(f\Total morphologies retrieved: {len(all_morphs)}\")
```

Notes:
- The entitysdk has multiple helpers; if it exposes a `.all()` or `.iterate()` convenience that automatically pages, prefer that. Example from docs: `client.search_entity(entity_type=CellMorphology).all()`.
- Always check the client response structure for fields like `items`, `total_items`, `limit`, `offset`, or built-in iterators.

---

## 3) Using the entitysdk convenience method shown in examples (single call)

## Listing cell morphologies with entitysdk (Python)

Below are idiomatic patterns based on the entitysdk examples.

### 1) Minimal — fetch a small number of morphologies
Use this when you want a quick preview (safe for large datasets).

```python
from entitysdk import models

# e.g., client = Client.from_env() or however you create it in your setup

```

### 2) Retrieve all cell morphologies (no client-side limit)
Use limit=None to let the SDK iterate through all pages for you.

```python
from entitysdk import models

# This returns an iterator that will page through results until exhausted
all_morphs = client.search_entity(entity_type=models.CellMorphology, limit=None)

count = 0
for morph in all_morphs:
    count += 1
    print(f"{count:4d} | ID: {morph.id} | Name: {morph.name}")

print(f"\nTotal morphologies iterated: {count}")
```

### 3) Search with filters (example: mtype preferred label or name ilike)
The query parameter accepts the same filter names used by the API. Use SQL-like ILIKE semantics when searching text fields.

```python
from entitysdk import models

# Find morphologies with a specific mtype pref label
iterator = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={\mtype__pref_label": \L5_TPC:A"},
    limit=50
)

for morph in iterator:
    print(f\ID: {morph.id} | Name: {morph.name} | MType: {morph.mtype}")
```

Or case-insensitive wildcard search (name__ilike):

```python
morphs_named = client.search_entity(
    entity_type=models.CellMorphology,
    query={
ame__ilike": "%pyramidal%"},
    limit=20
).all()  # .all() collects the page iterator into a list (if supported by your client)
```

### 4) Inspect metadata / counts (if returned by the SDK)
Some SDK iterator results or helper methods include metadata such as total_items. Check your client iterator object for attributes like `.meta` or API response fields. If not present, count as you iterate (see example 2).

### Notes / best practices
- Use limit=None to let the SDK automatically page through all results (examples in the docs show this pattern).
- Use `query` with API field names (e.g., `\mtype__pref_label\`, `
ame__ilike\`, `\subject__species__name\`) to filter results server-side.
- If you expect very large result sets, process items incrementally (iterate) instead of collecting into a single list in memory.

pricing_simulation_costs.expected_output:
## Simulation Costs

Simulation costs depend on your plan (Free or Pro) and the type of simulation you're running.

### Simulation Costs by Plan

| Simulation Type | Free Plan | Pro Plan |
|-----------------|-----------|----------|
| **E-model** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Ion channel** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Single cell** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Synaptome** | 1 credit/simulation | 0.5 credits/simulation |
| **Small microcircuit** (≤10 neurons) | 10 credits/simulation | 5 credits/simulation |
| **Microcircuit** (>10 neurons) | 0.05 credits/neuron/second of biological time | 0.025 credits/neuron/second of biological time |

### Credits Included

- **Free Plan:** 100 free initial credits (expire in 1 year)
- **Pro Plan Monthly:** 50 free credits/month (CHF 25/month)
- **Pro Plan Yearly:** 650 free credits/year (CHF 275/year)

### Cost Savings with Pro

The Pro plan offers approximately **50% cost reduction** on all simulation types:
- Basic simulations: 0.5 vs 1 credit
- Small microcircuits: 5 vs 10 credits
- Large microcircuits: Half the per-neuron cost

### Example Calculations

- **10 single cell simulations on Free:** 10 credits
- **10 single cell simulations on Pro:** 5 credits
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Free:** 5 credits (100 × 0.05)
- **100-neuron circuit for 1 second on Pro:** 2.5 credits (100 × 0.025)

Source: OBI pricing plans (Sanity planV2).

## How to compute the CHF cost for a simulation — examples

1) Example: Run a single-cell simulation on **Free** plan

2) Example: Run a **small microcircuit (≤10 neurons)** on **Pro** plan  
   - Cost: **5 credits / simulation** (Pro rate)  
   - At **0.09 CHF/credit** (1,000–4,999 pack) cost = 5 * 0.09 = **0.45 CHF** per simulation.

3) Example: Run a **microcircuit of 100 neurons** for **1 second** biological time on **Pro** plan

cerebellum_morphologies.ai_response:
I'll first find the brain region entry for \cerebellum\ to get its platform ID, then use that ID to fetch cell morphologies contained within the cerebellum. This resolves the correct brain region for the morphology query.The next step is to query cell morphologies within the cerebellum region using its platform ID so I can return five morphologies restricted to that brain region.## Results — 5 morphologies in the **Cerebellum**

I searched the platform for morphologies within the cerebellum region (ID **062ebc92-cebb-498a-a76d-b5ef1baf02cf**) and returned the first page of results. The query returned **total_items: 50** morphologies in this region; below are five items from page 1.

---

### 1) **soma_10c** — **ID: e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9**
- **Description:** Soma flask-like, radius ~7.5 µm; located in Purkinje cell layer. Large, flat, highly branched dendritic tree in molecular layer. Single long axon projecting to white matter (principal output).
- **MType:** *CBXpu_PuC* (Cerebellum Purkinje Cell) — id **fe3ab67b-26a8-4f4f-a451-03872bea7a08**
- **Assets (selected):**
  - **soma_10c.swc** — id **85f98df0-c8a1-4d37-b9af-dca010d4a8fe** (content_type: application/swc)
  - **soma_10c.h5** — id **e8008d5c-2c1a-417b-9d08-233cbdedb15e** (application/x-hdf5)
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
- **URL:** [View entity](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/e892fa95-c724-457a-8dc6-176f5d6cc5d9)

---

### 2) **01bc** — **ID: d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70**
- **Description:** Soma pyramidal/oval, radius ~6 µm; located in inner 1/3 of molecular layer. Dendrites long and straight with few branches; axon runs parallel to Purkinje layer with descending and ascending collaterals.
- **MType:** *CBXmo_BC* (Cerebellum Basket Cell) — id **cfa8f8f4-bf2b-43ac-9df8-23799032af68**
- **Assets (selected):**
  - **01bc.swc** — id **34723c67-7ead-41c9-bf43-f196299f1b97**
  - **01bc.h5** — id **743d29ba-ce48-4a85-aacd-beb9225146f4**
- **License:** CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
- **URL:** [View entity](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/d083a0bd-00a4-4594-b52f-950a5dd3ec70)

---

### 3) **stellate** — **ID: 00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53**
- **Description:** Small fusiform soma (~4 µm radius); located in outer 2/3 of molecular layer. Long, thin, aspinous dendrites branching in all directions. Axon branches immediately into short circumscribed collaterals.
- **MType:** *CBXmo_StC* (Cerebellum Stellate Cell) — id **c38dca49-4ceb-4d22-a518-5dff1ab59e90**
- **Assets (selected):**
  - **stellate.swc** — id **4503498e-f4cb-4c97-92fa-f111d457d8df**

- **URL:** [View entity](https://openbraininstitute.org/app/entity/00ba95d3-13e4-4703-ad85-3df816febf53)

---

morphology_studies.user: What are some recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum?
morphology_studies.ai_response:
To find recent, relevant papers on neuron morphology in the cerebrum, I'll run an academic literature search targeting recent studies (morphology, cortical/cerebral neurons, dendrites/axons) and return the most relevant results with brief summaries and links.## Recent studies on neuron morphology in the cerebrum

Below are several recent, high-impact papers focused on neuronal morphology in cerebral cortex regions (prefrontal and visual cortex). I selected these because they provide large-scale, single-neuron reconstructions and data-driven maps of dendritic/axonal diversity — useful if you want morphometric rules, cell-type/morphology relationships, or atlases for modeling.

### 1) Single-neuron analysis of dendrites and axons reveals the network organization in mouse prefrontal cortex  
- **Citation:** Le Gao et al., *Nature Neuroscience* (2023)  
- **Why this is relevant:** Provides nearly 2,000 complete dendrite + axon morphologies from mouse prefrontal cortex (PFC), characterizes somatodendritic scaling across layers, identifies 24 dendritic subtypes among pyramidal neurons, and links morphology to electrophysiological phenotypes and projection patterns. This is a rich resource for circuit-level morphology and connectivity inference.  
- **Link:** [Single‑neuron analysis of dendrites and axons (Nature Neuroscience)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41593-023-01339-y?error=cookies_not_supported&code=473b0b6a-f6a9-45f3-a4eb-fc499b0481aa)  
- ![Dendrite/axon figure from PFC study](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41593-023-01339-y/MediaObjects/41593_2023_1339_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 2) An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology in the mouse visual cortex  
- **Citation:** Marissa A. Weis et al., *Nature Communications* (2025) — *Open access*  
- **Why this is relevant:** Uses graph-based, unsupervised methods on ~30,000 excitatory neuron reconstructions (MICrONS EM volume) to define a low-dimensional morphological “barcode”. Concludes that excitatory cortical morphology is better described as a continuum (with some layer-specific exceptions) rather than discrete m‑types — important for morphological classification and large-scale modeling.  
- **Link:** [An unsupervised map of excitatory neuron dendritic morphology (Nature Communications, 2025)](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-025-58763-w)  
- ![Morphology map figure from visual cortex study](https://media.springernature.com/m685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1038%2Fs41467-025-58763-w/MediaObjects/41467_2025_58763_Fig1_HTML.png)

### 3) Related/resource-type papers you may find useful
- Morphological diversity and whole‑brain morphometry studies (2021–2024) and other MICrONS-based single-neuron connectivity/morphology integration papers are often cited alongside the above two; these offer additional datasets and methods for large-scale morphological analysis. (If you want, I can list specific earlier references and datasets.)

---

Next step: if you want full-text access or detailed data (figures, methods, or supplementary datasets) from any of these papers, I can attempt to retrieve the full articles or extract specific sections (methods, datasets, figures) for a deeper look. Which paper(s) should I fetch in full?

me_model_glossary.user: What is the definition of an ME-model?
me_model_glossary.expected_output:
## ME-model (glossary entry)

**Name:** **ME-model**  
**ID:** **IYthF0bAW1gjnJ64ATi2TT**

**Description:**  
An ME-model, or *morphoelectric model*, is a combination of an E-model with relevant morphology. ME-models can be simulated using [BlueCelluLab](https://github.com/openbraininstitute/BlueCelluLab) and can serve as essential elements in circuit building.

**Definition (official):**  
An ME-model, or morphoelectric model, is a combination of an E-model with relevant morphology. ME-models can be simulated using BlueCellulab and can serve as essential elements in circuit building.

Source: Official platform glossary (OBI Sanity).
me_model_glossary.ai_response:
## Definition — ME-model

**ME-model** stands for **Morphology + Electrophysiology model** (commonly written *ME-model*).  
An ME-model is a computational single-neuron model that combines:

- **Morphology** — a reconstructed 3D neuronal structure (soma, dendrites, axon) that specifies geometry and compartmentalization; and  
- **Electrophysiology (E-model)** — a set of biophysical membrane properties and ion-channel mechanisms (passive properties, active conductances, synaptic mechanisms, membrane capacitance, axial resistivity, etc.) mapped onto the morphological compartments.

### Key characteristics
- **Anatomically detailed:** Uses the real or synthetic morphology to determine compartment sizes and branching.  
- **Biophysically realistic:** Contains conductance-based ion-channel models and membrane parameters that reproduce firing and subthreshold behavior.  
- **Compartmental simulation ready:** Formulated for compartmental solvers (e.g., NEURON) so that electrical dynamics are simulated across the morphology.  
- **Parameterized:** Includes parameter values (channel densities, kinetics, membrane constants) and often metadata about species, brain region, and experimental provenance.

### Typical contents
- Morphology file (e.g., SWC or similar) or morphology object  
- Ion-channel models and distributions (channel types and density across compartments)  
- Passive properties: Rm, Cm, Ra  
- Mechanisms for synaptic inputs (weight, kinetics) if included  
- Metadata: species, cell type, source data, fitting/validation details

### Uses
- Reproducing and predicting single-cell electrophysiological responses (spike patterns, subthreshold dynamics)  
- Testing mechanisms of excitability and dendritic integration  
- Serving as building blocks for circuits and network simulations (when combined with connectivity rules)  
- Parameter optimization and fitting to experimental recordings

If you want, I can show an example ME-model entry from the Open Brain Platform (fields typically present) or retrieve a specific ME-model available in the database. Which would you prefer?

metrics.name: Correctness [GEval]

## High‑impact computational neuroscientists (selected)

- **Terrence J. Sejnowski**  
  - Key contributions: Neural networks, synaptic plasticity, Independent Component Analysis (ICA), Boltzmann machines; leadership connecting neuroscience and AI (NeurIPS).  
  - Awards / recognition: The Brain Prize profile; member of multiple academies.  
  - Source: [Terrence J. Sejnowski — The Brain Prize profile](https://brainprize.org/winners/computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-2024/terrence-j-sejnowski)  
  ![Terrence Sejnowski](https://www.brainprize.org/files/styles/open_graph/public/media/image/Terry_winners_2024_0.png?h=33f5e883&itok=Sk0BI0wV)

- **Larry F. Abbott**  
  - Key contributions: Theoretical frameworks for neural dynamics, mean-field approaches, models of learning and memory.  
  - Awards / recognition: Co-recipient of The Brain Prize 2024 (with Sejnowski & Sompolinsky).  
  - Source: [Lundbeck Foundation press release — The Brain Prize 2024](https://lundbeckfonden.com/news/pioneering-work-in-computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-is-awarded-the-worlds-largest#:~:text=Professors%20Larry%20Abbott%2C%20Terrence%20Sejnowski,of%20brain%2Dinspired%20artificial%20intelligence.)

- **Haim Sompolinsky**  
  - Key contributions: Theory of chaotic dynamics in neural networks, population coding, statistical mechanics approaches to neural systems.  
  - Awards / recognition: Co-recipient of The Brain Prize 2024.  
  - Source: [Lundbeck Foundation press release — The Brain Prize 2024](https://lundbeckfonden.com/news/pioneering-work-in-computational-and-theoretical-neuroscience-is-awarded-the-worlds-largest#:~:text=Professors%20Larry%20Abbott%2C%20Terrence%20Sejnowski,of%20brain%2Dinspired%20artificial%20intelligence.)

- **John J. Hopfield**  
  - Key contributions: Hopfield networks (associative memory), foundational work linking physics and neural computation.  
  - Awards / recognition: Widely celebrated; featured in retrospectives about Nobel‑winning work in related AI fields.  
  - Sources: [PNAS profile referencing Hopfield and Hinton](https://www.pnas.org/doi/abs/10.1073/pnas.2423094122) and review pieces such as the Sainsbury Wellcome blog on 2024 laureates.  
  ![PNAS key image](https://www.pnas.org/cms/asset/5ccebd5e-3c5a-4725-b0c3-beaf7b6b349d/keyimage.jpg)

- **Geoffrey E. Hinton**  
  - Key contributions: Backpropagation and deep learning foundations, Boltzmann machines; major influence on modern neural networks and connections to neuroscience.  
  - Awards / recognition: Among the 2024 Nobel-recognized figures in profiles discussing the AI–neuroscience interface (see review coverage).  
  - Source: [Sainsbury Wellcome Centre blog — Hopfield, Hinton, Hassabis: 2024 Nobel laureates shaping neuroscience](https://www.sainsburywellcome.org/web/blog/hopfield-hinton-and-hassabis-2024-nobel-laureates-shaping-neuroscience)

- **Tomaso A. Poggio**

  - Awards / recognition: Swartz Prize laureate (2014) among other honors.  
  - Source: [Tomaso Poggio — Wikipedia summary/profile](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tomaso_Poggio)

- **David C. Marr** (historical)  
  - Key contributions: Foundational conceptual framework for computational neuroscience (levels of analysis: computational, algorithmic, implementational); influential early models of vision.  
  - Recognition: Marr’s work is canonical in the field and still widely cited.

- **Nancy Kopell, Kenneth D. Miller, Xiao-Jing Wang, Ila Fiete, Misha Tsodyks, Eero Simoncelli** (representative additional influential theorists)

software_docs_obione.user: Please show me a code example of how to create a single cell simulation using the obione package.
software_docs_obione.expected_output:
## Single Cell Simulation Example (OBI-One)

Below is a step-by-step single-cell simulation example using the OBI-One Python API (openbraininstitute/obi-one). It shows how to:

- select an MEModel (morphology+electrical model),
- build and validate a simulation configuration (stimulus, recordings, timestamps),
- generate a grid-scan / single simulation,
- and run the simulation with BlueCelluLab (the usual backend used in OBI-One examples).

You will need obi_one installed and configured, plus credentials / db_client as required by your environment. Replace placeholder IDs (e.g., <MEMODEL-ID>) and file paths with real values.

### 1) Select an MEModel to simulate
```python
# Option A: use a known MEModel ID
entity_ID = \"<MEMODEL-ID>\  # <<< Replace with real MEModel UUID

# Option B: (interactive selection helper used in examples)
# memodel_ids = get_entities.get_entities(\memodel\", token, memodel_ids,
#                                         project_context=project_context,
#                                         multi_select=False,
#                                         default_scale=\small\")
# memodel_ids[0] would then be used below
```

### 2) Build the MEModel simulation configuration (form API)
```python
from pathlib import Path
import obi_one as obi

# === Parameters ===
sim_duration = 3000.0  # ms

# Create an empty config for MEModel-based simulation
sim_conf = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# Info block
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\MEModel Simulation\",
    campaign_description=\Single-cell MEModel simulation with constant current stimulus\"
)
sim_conf.set(info, name=\info\")

# Regular timestamps (example: a single repetition covering simulation)
regular_timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=0.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=sim_duration)
sim_conf.add(regular_timestamps, name='RegularTimestamps')

# Somatic current clamp stimulus (Constant current)
stimulus = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=regular_timestamps.ref,
    duration=2000.0,
    amplitude=0.5  # nA (example)
)
sim_conf.add(stimulus, name=\CurrentClampInput\")

# Record soma voltage
voltage_recording = obi.SomaVoltageRecording()
sim_conf.add(voltage_recording, name='VoltageRecording')

# Optionally limit the time window recorded
time_window_voltage_recording = obi.TimeWindowSomaVoltageRecording(start_time=0.0, end_time=2000.0)
sim_conf.add(time_window_voltage_recording, name='TimeWindowVoltageRecording')

# Initialization: point to the MEModel by ID and set simulation length
simulations_initialize = obi.MEModelSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.MEModelFromID(id_str=entity_ID),
    simulation_length=sim_duration
)
sim_conf.set(simulations_initialize, name='initialize')

# Validate and get validated configuration object
validated_sim_conf = sim_conf.validated_config()
print(\Validated config:\", validated_sim_conf)
```

### 3) Wrap config into a GridScan / single simulation configuration
(OBI-One uses GridScan tasks to generate concrete config files; for a single point you still create a grid with a single cell)
```python
# Create a GridScan generation task for the validated form
grid_scan = obi.GridScanGenerationTask(
    form=validated_sim_conf,
    coordinate_directory_option=\ZERO_INDEX\",
    output_root='../../../obi-output/memodel_simulations/grid_scan'  # change to desired output
)

# (Optional) inspect multi-value parameters or coordinates
grid_scan.multiple_value_parameters(display=True)
grid_scan.coordinate_parameters(display=True)

# Execute generation (requires db_client configured)
grid_scan.execute(db_client=db_client)
```

### 4) Run the generated simulation with BlueCelluLab backend
```python
from obi_one.scientific.library.simulation_execution import run

# Path to simulation_config.json from generated single config
simulation_config_path = grid_scan.single_configs[0].coordinate_output_root / \simulation_config.json\"
print(\Simulation config path:\", simulation_config_path)

# Run the simulation (bluecellulab is typical)
run(
    simulation_config=simulation_config_path,
    simulatorluecellulab\",  # or 
eurodamus\"
    save_nwb=False  # optionally save NWB
)
```

### 5) Load and analyze results with bluepysnap
```python
import bluepysnap

snap_simulation = bluepysnap.Simulation(simulation_config_path)
spikes = snap_simulation.spikes

print(\spikes time_start, time_stop, dt:\", spikes.time_start, spikes.time_stop, spikes.dt)
print(\population names:\", spikes.population_names)

# Access soma voltage report
soma_report = snap_simulation.reports['SomaVoltage']
print(\SomaVoltage time_start, time_stop, dt:\", soma_report.time_start, soma_report.time_stop, soma_report.dt)

# Example: inspect the head of the spike report dataframe
filtered = spikes.filter(t_start=spikes.time_start, t_stop=spikes.time_stop)
print(filtered.report.head())
```

## Notes, tips and placeholders
- **Replace** <MEMODEL-ID> with the actual MEModel UUID from EntityCore.
- You need a configured db_client variable (OBI-One examples use a DB client for GridScan generation) \u2014 ensure you have credentials and environment set up as per your installation.
- If you prefer to pick an MEModel interactively or via EntityCore queries, use the platform's EntityCore helpers to get MEModel IDs (examples in the repository show interactive selection).
- The examples above are adapted from the OBI-One example notebooks:
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_simulation.ipynb
  - examples/F_single_cell_simulations/entitysdk_memodel_with_synapses_simulation.ipynb

If you want, I can:
- provide a minimal runnable script adjusted to your environment (if you give me the MEModel ID and where your db_client/config is stored),
- or show how to query EntityCore for available MEModels and pick one programmatically. Which would you like?
software_docs_obione.ai_response:
To provide an accurate, up-to-date code example I'll fetch the current documentation for the OBI Python package that manages simulations so I can base the example on the official API and recommended usage. Next, I'll retrieve the documentation for the 'openbraininstitute/obi-one' package.## Single-cell simulation example (obi-one / Python)

Below is a compact, ready-to-run example that builds a single-cell simulation configuration using the `obi_one` package. It selects a single neuron by ID, injects a short somatic current pulse, records the soma voltage, validates the configuration and prints it. Replace the placeholder IDs (circuit_id and neuron id) with actual values from your project.

Rationale for the next step: to set up a single-cell run we first define the neuron set, timestamps, stimulus and recording blocks and then provide an initialization block that ties the config to a circuit (by ID) and the simulation length; validation ensures the config matches obi-one's schema.

```python
# Single-cell simulation with obi-one
# Replace the placeholders: circuit_id and neuron_id with actual IDs from your project

import obi_one as obi

# --- Simulation parameters ---
sim_duration = 500.0  # ms
circuit_id = \13a54362-0c99-43fd-94e4-58bdb5b79466\   # <-- replace with your circuit UUID
neuron_id = 42                                        # <-- replace with your single neuron index/ID

# --- 1) Create an empty CircuitSimulationScanConfig ---
config = obi.CircuitSimulationScanConfig.empty_config()

# --- 2) Metadata (optional) ---
info = obi.Info(
    campaign_name=\Single-cell test",
    campaign_description=\Single neuron current clamp test"
)
config.set(info, name=\info")

# --- 3) Neuron set: single neuron by ID ---
# Use IDNeuronSet with a single element so the simulation targets one cell
single_neuron_set = obi.IDNeuronSet(
    neuron_ids=obi.NamedTuple(elements=(neuron_id,), name=\single_neuron")
)
config.add(single_neuron_set, name=\SingleNeuronSet")

# --- 4) Timestamps ---
# A single stimulus time at 50 ms (RegularTimestamps with 1 repetition)
timestamps = obi.RegularTimestamps(start_time=50.0, number_of_repetitions=1, interval=1.0)
config.add(timestamps, name=\Timestamps")

# --- 5) Stimulus: somatic current-clamp pulse ---
current_stim = obi.ConstantCurrentClampSomaticStimulus(
    timestamps=timestamps.ref,  # reference to timestamps block
    duration=5.0,               # ms
    delay=0.0,                  # relative to timestamp
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    amplitude=0.3               # nA (adjust as needed)
)
config.add(current_stim, name=\SomaticPulse")

# --- 6) Recording: soma voltage for the single neuron ---
soma_rec = obi.SomaVoltageRecording(
    neuron_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    start_time=0.0,
    end_time=sim_duration
)
config.add(soma_rec, name=\SomaVoltage")

# --- 7) Initialization: link to circuit and set simulation length ---
initialize = obi.CircuitSimulationScanConfig.Initialize(
    circuit=obi.CircuitFromID(id_str=circuit_id),
    node_set=single_neuron_set.ref,
    simulation_length=sim_duration,
    v_init=-70.0,         # mV, initial membrane potential
    random_seed=1
)
config.set(initialize, name=\initialize")

# --- 8) Validate final configuration ---
validated_config = config.validated_config()

# Print or inspect the validated configuration
print(\Validated simulation configuration:")
print(validated_config)
```

Next step: after the configuration is validated, the typical workflow is to submit this config to the platform's simulation service or run it via the obi-one service/CLI used in your environment — let me know if you want an example of how to submit/run the validated config (and provide whether you use the local obi-one runner, a remote service, or EntityCore-managed execution).
